awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Low-Loss and Tunable Optical Huygens Metasurfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: This CAREER project seeks to control the behavior of light by using very small antennae, also known as nanostructured metasurfaces. The research seeks to minimize inefficiencies in these metasurfaces while using them to control the behavior of light on-demand. The principal investigator envisions applications where solar panels can harvest more sunlight, communications can function with significant enhancement in speed, smartphone camera lenses can be improved, windows can adjust their transparency to trap or release heat from buildings, and computer displays can become mirrors with the flick of a switch. This research activity is integrated with efforts to train the next generation of materials scientists and engineers, specifically through the launch of a new materials PhD program. In addition, a mentoring-focused summer research experience for middle school students aims to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups, and members of the greater New Orleans community in general, in science research and education.

Technical description: Fundamental new materials insights are required to manipulate the phase and amplitude of light at the nanoscale through optical metasurfaces that are both low-loss and easily tunable. Successful platforms may serve as a key building block for a range of applications, such as high speed encoding of orbital angular momentum for optical communications. This CAREER project investigates low-loss Huygens metasurfaces as a platform for dynamically tunable optics. The metasurfaces are composed of optical nanoantennae that strongly interact with both the electric and magnetic fields of incident waves. Numerical techniques are used to design metasurfaces composed of tunable optical materials such as vanadium dioxide. Metasurfaces are synthesized using nanofabrication techniques. Properties are characterized vs. tuning parameter (e.g. electrical or thermal stimulus) using a suite of optical and materials analysis tools, including measurement of phase shift, light deflection, and ultrafast response. Properties of these materials are investigated through three subtasks, analyzing optical tunability in single-layer metasurfaces, multi-layer metasurfaces, as well as spatially addressable ones. These research objectives are integrated with educational efforts that emphasize mentoring and hands-on learning about photonic materials for students in middle school through the graduate level. Activities include developing new course content, a new materials PhD program, a materials summer camp for high school students, and research experiences for middle school students.

por.por_cntn:
Light interacts with materials all around us, and we experience these interactions in innumerable beneficial ways, both natural and technology-enabled. As we seek new ways to use light to benefit humanity, the study of light interactions with new materials opens pathways to technological advances in medicine, communications, augmented reality, sustainable energy use, and much more.

In this NSF CAREER project, we investigated a new type of engineered material - optical metasurfaces - that uses nanoscale designs to create novel light interactions. In particular, we focused on metasurfaces with performance that may be tuned even after the structure is fabricated. These materials can achieve desirable functions in very small, flat form factor that may become components of photonic integrated circuits and other compact devices. 

Intellectual Merit: Over the course of this five-year project, we investigated very sensitive (Huygens) optical metasurfaces from three different materials.

(1) Silicon metasurfaces were placed in a microfluidic channel. Through a series of successive developments, we ultimately built a shoebox-sized portable refractive index and biosensor. The sensor showed sensitivity to changes in refractive index of a fluid as sensitive as a large benchtop instrument for <5% of the cost. Furthermore, through selective surface adhesion, we were able to detect the presence of tuberculosis biomarkers in a fluid at concentrations similar to those in human fluids. Such a metasurface sensor has potential for integration into handheld or wearable diagnostics.

(2) Vanadium dioxide, a material that changes from an insulator to a metal at about 60-70 degC, was deployed as a tunable metasurface for a wide range of potential uses, from tunable holograms to high-speed optical amplitude and phase modulators. We developed new methods of synthesis and nanofabrication for this challenging material and showed its potential for continuous modulation of light intensity and phase. Such a device may be used to increase the speed of optical communications.

(3) Antimony trisulfide was investigated due to its ability to be tuned from one optical state to another with low optical loss. We developed ultra-thin (few hundred nanometer thick) optical lenses from this material that can be tuned from one focal length to another through an external switching mechanism.

Additional developments in optical interferometry and in understanding the fundamental interactions of light within and between nanoantennas complemented these outcomes.

Broader Impacts: In addition to the potential benefits of these research developments for future applications, this project achieved several other broader goals. Five graduate students and seven undergraduate students were mentored through hands-on involvement in this research, with a majority pursuing directly-related careers in their next steps.

LightLab, a new outreach program developed by the PI, was established to host New Orleans middle school students from underrepresented communities for a one-week, fully immersive research experience in our optics lab and nanofabrication facility. Twenty-one students from three cohorts participated, including several who returned for multiple years. The quality and enthusiasm of their research presentations, alongside survey data, indicated program success. The PI's research group also regularly participated in established Tulane outreach activities through the Tulane Science Scholars Program (TSSP, high school), Boys at Tulane in STEM (BATS, middle school), and Girls in STEM at Tulane (GIST, middle school).

Over the course of this project, the PI co-led the development of a new masters and PhD program in Materials Engineering at Tulane, the first of their kind in the state of Louisiana. These programs are now fully developed, with graduated students achieving success by moving into their chosen materials-related careers. In support of these graduate programs and related undergraduate programs, the PI has created two new courses at Tulane on Photonic Materials and Devices and Semiconductor Devices.
